title: 103_s848
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to allow haying and grazing on reduced acreage, conservation use acreage, and diverted production acreage, with restrictions set by the State committee. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to allow haying and grazing on reduced acreage, conservation use acreage, and diverted production acreage, with restrictions set by the State committee. Producers can elect to pay a fee for grazing or haying as established by the Bureau of Land Management. The State committee, in consultation with wildlife agencies, establishes a 5-month period for land management from April 1 to October 31. The Secretary cannot exclude irrigated acreage not planted with alfalfa. Amendments allow haying and grazing on specific acreage with fees set by the Bureau of Land Management. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to allow haying and grazing on reduced acreage, conservation use acreage, and diverted acreage, except during a 5-month period set by the State committee. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to allow haying and grazing on reduced acreage, conservation use acreage, and diverted acreage, except during a 5-month period set by the State committee. Producers can pay a fee for grazing or haying based on Bureau of Land Management fees. The State committee, in consultation with wildlife agencies, establishes a 5-month period from April 1 to October 31 for haying and grazing. The Secretary cannot exclude irrigated acreage not planted with alfalfa.
